row.Text: Powder choice and amount is just one part of the equation. The bullet's ballistics also depend on bullet weight and barrel length.
I was thinking loading might make a difference, but I'm not sure (which is why I asked).
Very true. I generally use Hornady .224 FMJ boattail with cannelure, and shoot it solely out of my AR-15, so accuracy is only as good as the platform it's shooting out of, to be sure.

You need to enter more information. A bullet is not the only component to decide accuracy. Especially in pistol caliber rounds. You don't even mention whether these are pistol or rifle rounds you are talking about.
Loading can...but that's more than just the diameter of the bullet.
For those who don't know, FTF means "failure to feed."
For example, my 1911 (in .45 auto) is generally more accurate right at 875 ft/s than at 1050 ft/s with the same bullet.
I edited in pistol. I understand there are many components to accuracy, I only want the difference based on bullet type irregardless of what the other factors are.
Even inside pistol cartridges there are many types. This question is vague and pointless without other factors.
As per the size of the shell argument...the 16" guns on a modern battleship are generally .22 MOA, a _really_ good custom 1911 is probably going to be somewhere around 2-3 MOA.
No, it's not pointless. If I wanted to buy a new Glock, and was looking for which one would be more accurate, then I need to know if using a 40 would be better than a 45, or vice-versa.
And this question would not answer that. I could just as easily assume you mean .45 ACP as I could .45 GAP or .45 LC. Your question is not complete.
Bullets != Cartridges.
And you can make a .22 caliber bullet that will be .5 MOA. Your assertion that accuracy is dependent on bullet diameter is a false one.
Make a .22 caliber .22 MOA and get back to me... ;-)

This question is not specific enough to answer -- the right answer will differ based on things like what type of round you are talking about, what specific pistol, etc. Please edit it with more details, then flag for moderator attention and it can be re-opened.

If you notice, I said that there were MORE things than just bullet diameter that affect accuracy. But generally speaking, it's easier to make a larger diameter bullet accurate than it is to make a smaller one.

The problem is not that the floating firing pin may cause a discharge in the AR15. The .223 and 5.56 rounds use hard primers to offset this. There ARE issues with floating firing pins continually striking rounds but this is not one of them.
GEOCHET is correct, repeated chambering does carry the possibility of cartridge setback. I have also seen it. There are also other important issues as I have identified in my answer below.

Just because a manufacturer claims that their rifle is chambered in 5.56x45mm does not necessarily mean that the rifle has a milspec 5.56mm chamber. There are some AR manufacturers whose "5.56mm" chambers are actually .223 or Wylde.

@Chris: If your rifle is marked for a 5.56 chamber, it can fire either .223 or 5.56. 'Mil-spec' has nothing to do with this. Either the chamber is able to handle the increased pressure from having the 5.56 round in it, or it isn't. If you have reason to believe my answer is wrong and that the XM15-E2S cannot handle 5.56 ammunition, feel free to cite your source.

I'm not saying anything about whether it's safe to fire .223. What I am saying is that some AR manufacturers state that their rifles are chambered for 5.56mm when they really aren't. This doesn't impact their ability to safely fire either type of ammunition, but it does affect reliability.
Once again, if you have information that the XM15-E2S is not properly chambered, please cite your source.

It's true that there will always be a degree of subjectivity to this question as far as how much time and money you are willing to spend and what you're willing to bet your life on. I think I'll settle on the 100-200 answer for now. Does anyone have an actual statistical analysis?

A handgun will fire tens of thousands of rounds during its practical lifetime, and 100-200 is an insignificant amount unless you are attempting to observe something very specific, rather than something general (like overall reliability). Assuming a service life of 30,000 rounds (half what most guns are capable of before frames and slides start to see wear), 200 is only 0.6% of total rounds fired, and not a significant indicator. 1000 rounds would be 3% of total rounds fired and an acceptable indicator of overall performance.

Changing it to include semi-auto shotguns would change the answers given. I've yet to see a "tactical" semi-auto with bead sights, while 870 Police and Mossburg 500 series shotguns are available with them. They seem to be a specific consideration to tactical pump shotguns.

@RobertCartaino: No problem. I asked the question specifically to generate discussion during the beta and I agree with your take on things. Should I have opened a meta question instead or was this the right way to handle it?

Overly simple questions are generally frowned upon, especially really early in a beta because the front page becomes your site design. You want to start this site off asking interesting questions; Not the basic questions you find on any other site. So if you have a question about the site's scope, you can always ask in meta. But, certainly, if you have an actual question about the subject, it's fine to just ask your question here.

Chris's comment is relevant and should not be downplayed or argued. It is dangerous to fire 5.56 in a firearm not designed specifically for it, so whenever this question comes up, the right answer is "call the manufacturer to verify if the chamber is in fact able to handle a 5.56 round." If you're still not satisfied that their answer is accurate, don't take the risk. Remember, we're talking about people's health and safety here.

"Similarly, the BC is not affected by velocity" I have to disagree here. If a projectile were a perfect match for the reference projectile, BC would not be affected by velocity. Since most bullets aren't a very good match for the G1 reference projectile, BC can vary quite a bit by velocity. Sierra acknowledges this and provides velocity banded BCs for their bullets. A better solution is to use the G7 BC instead, since that's a much better match for a boat tail rifle round.

There isn't much that you can do with a 25¢ trigger job that you can't do by shooting a few thousand rounds through your gun. Also be aware that you run the risk of damaging parts that will need to be replaced. Potential problems include multiple fires per trigger pull and failure of the trigger to reset after firing if you do too much polishing. The parts you can break can be replaced rather inexpensively, however. Finally, if this is a gun you're going to bet your life on or carry on duty in some way, either let a gunsmith do the work or don't do it at all.

Enlighten me: what is a 2011?

A 2011 is a high-capacity pistol fashioned after the 1911, with a few other improvements. Most 2011 parts are 1911 compatible, except the trigger which has a wider bow on the 2011, the magazine release, which is longer, and the grip. The 2011 uses a one-piece molded stock and trigger guard that are screwed to a metal receiver. The safety-plunger tunnel is integral to the frame, and I'm probably forgetting a few of the smaller changes.

The manual of arms is almost totally irrelevant. The only things that will stay the same are pulling the trigger and setting the safety. Loading, reloading, malfunction clearing, and operating the bolt are totally different. What is your intended use for this rifle? Do you reload? The upper may not be expensive but bullets in all of those calibers are (price increasing with size).

What will you use it for? Why do you want to use this caliber? Why have you eliminated 9mm? What other guns have you looked at? And most importantly, again, what will you use it for? Your question is SEVERELY lacking.

It comes down to quality control and the materials used. If they magnetic-partical-inspect bolts at all, they do it only by batch and not all bolts individually. They may or may not do high pressure test rounds on bolts. They use lower quality steel in the barrels. They don't properly stake the gas keys on the bolt carrier. They use improper diameter buffer tubes ("commercial" diameter vs. the proper spec diameter). A large number of small things. They're fine as a hobby gun but they won't last if you run them hard. They're not known as "work guns" or "fighting guns" since they're low quality.

Police officers usually prefer a manual safety for weapon retention purposes. A lot of police officers are killed when their own weapon is taken from them during a physical struggle. Due to the variety of safety systems and pistols, it can take the suspect a few seconds before he figures out how to disable the safety. This small window of opportunity allows the officer to either attempt to disarm the suspect or go for his back-up gun. The same reasoning also comes into play with civilians who open-carry because whoever they are an altercation with will go for the gun first.

A quibble on your point#4 - the entire mass of the powder charge is ejected from the barrel, and therefore contributes to recoil. It doesn't matter if it is a gas or a solid, mass is mass. In fact, fully-burnt powder will give more recoil than partly-burnt powder - it is the same mass, but because more energy has been released the speed of the exiting gun gas is higher. For what it's worth a reasonably good S.W.A.G. of the average speed of the gun gas is 5000-6000fps for rifles.

The magazine spring is also working hardest when you've got a full magazine - perhaps the spring is either a little too weak or a little too strong, making it tougher to get the first round out of the magazine, and that little bit of extra effort/delay is causing your problem.

@kbyrd - The mag spring is at its maximum tension with the first round, so your slide has to work a little harder to strip that round. You might try loading your magazines with a round or two less to see if the problem goes away (probably not your technique) or continues (might be you).

As an NRA certified instructor, I would suggest that NRA certification is inadequate to identify a good instructor. Look for recommendations or feedback on an instructor. NRA certification means they *should* know what they're doing, but it doesn't mean that they're a good instructor.

It probably doesn't apply in this case, but the statement that "Springs are weakened by overuse, rather than by staying compressed." is only true if the spring is used within its elastic limit. Magazines made for certain competitions (USPSA / IPSC) are often used beyond their elastic limit for the sake of maximizing capacity. These springs do fatigue, and quickly. Magazines using them are generally never left loaded, and I find it necessary to replace these springs annually (even though the mags are only left loaded during a match) in order to assure reliability.

What kind of pressure would need to be exerted to strike the primer and make the ammo fire, though? Could it happen without the use of a specific tool?

The force required depends on the primer. Some strikers are in the 15 to 30 lb range, but that's a wild guess as to the actual pressure exerted, because pressure increases as surface area decreases. I've dropped shotgun shells (which have fairly large primers) countless times. I've never heard of bullets going off from being dropped myself.

"If you see another customer doing something dangerous (like sweeping the muzzle around the entire store) tell your counter person. ... If the employees look at you like you're being silly, leave." +1 for this alone (the rest of the answer is great too)!

@geerlingguy - the direction and location of the force is really what's important. In reloading I have mangled primers (flattened sideways, crushed sides, completely crumpled, all without setting the primer off. The force must be very concentrated, very close to the center of the primer (where the anvil and cup meet inside) or the primer will not detonate.

Any idea if steel core ammunition is lead-based as well (combination of steel + lead)? Many ranges I know of ban steel core for fear of fire (despite the fact they lack steel targets on said range).

@Jack Steel cored ammo may have no lead (just a jacketed lead core) or have a core of lead and steel. The reason for the lead and steel core is to try to get the best of both worlds: the density of lead, and the penetration of steel. The solid steel core bullets have a lower ballistic coefficient due to their reduced density. This means they lose velocity faster and are more adversely affected by wind.

Doesn't have anything to do with modern metallurgy or tension, and has everything to do with use. A 40 year old Mustang that's been in a barn for 39 years will have much better springs than a 10 year old cop car that's been used hard for 10 years.

*Technically*, the bullet will have left the barrel by the time the gas shock wave travels down the gas tube and starts to move the bolt backwards. In a piston driven system, the bullet probably *hasn't* left the barrel by the time the bolt starts to move backwards, because the speed of sound in the metal piston is so much higher than the speed of sound in air. Of course, it doesn't matter because good factory ammo is going to make the gun do the same thing every time.

Granted use will fatigue springs much faster than storage under tension (especially with the dynamic loading you find in a firearm or a car!). But physics is physics and storage under tension will fatigue the part faster than storage with all or most of the tension relieved.

Your car is a great example, we will take your Mustang stored in a barn (the springs are under minimal tension for the application). Next to it we will park another Mustang with 4,000 pounds of lead in the trunk and engine bay (maximum loading). 10 years later we put them both on the road - car one will have better springs.

Creep: http://www.engineersedge.com/material_science/creep.htm -- "With most of the engineering alloys used in construction at room temperature or lower, creep strain is so small at working loads that it can safely be ignored. It does not become significant until the stress intensity is approaching the fracture failure strength."

Fatigue: http://www.sv.vt.edu/classes/MSE2094_NoteBook/97ClassProj/anal/kelly/fatigue.html -- "Fatigue occurs when a material is subject to alternating stresses, over a long period of time. Examples of where Fatigue may occur are: springs, turbine blades, airplane wings, bridges and bones."

There are actually some small difference between 7.62 NATO and .308 (Winchester). The .308 Winchester was accepted as the military standard, but the SAAMI specs were altered slightly. More info: http://www.thefirearmblog.com/blog/2007/09/03/308-winchester-vs-762x51-nato/

I'd insert 7.62 x 39 at #2.5, being very similar to the .30-30 ballistically. The 7.62x54R at 4.9, being very close to the .30-06. The 7.62 NATO I'd put squarely at #4 as it's *virtually* identical to the .308. The 5.45x39 I'd put around #3, near the .223 - that particular ranking being the most arbitrary, imo.

The rust colored grease that comes with Glock isn't magical, it's just copper anti-seize grease. It prevents a user from having a bad first impression if they take the gun straight from the dealer to the range without first lubricating it. It's OK to remove it once the operator settle's on a regular lubrication treatment, or you could leave it in and add oil in addition to it.
I'll just add to check the barrel for obstructions or debris.
Additionally, the altered density can cause accuracy issues with "incorrect" barrel twist rates.
Also, while you're checking the barrel please run a CLP-soaked patch through it once or twice to clean out any debris or shipping lubricant.
Good points. I don't attribute magical properties to it, but Glock recommends leaving it in place until it's gone.

I think you're throwing out a few strawman arguments. No quality lead-based bullet is going to lose "~15-30%" mass - that's worst case, worst quality ammo. Similarly results at 100 yards are deceptive, because that's where non-lead ammo can compete. Extend the results to 400 yards and let's have a comparison. Your lead-free ammo has been blown another 30% farther by wind (which means that the error in wind estimation is even more troublesome) and of course you've lost much more momentum / energy than a denser (lead) bullet would have.
There are (or have been) some superior lead-free bullets but they are prohibitively expensive, illegal (due to 'cop killer' legislation) or no longer existent.

In general, what are your concerns as a lefty using a semi-auto shotgun? I'm a lefty as well, maybe I can offer tips on how to make using a right-handed shotgun easier. I'm not insisting you should, it's just that by requiring a left-handed action, you limit your choices.
@kbyrd more of just wanted to know what options there are. Currently I use an o/u and was looking at getting a semi-auto for duck.

If you pick a popular shotgun, you can often find parts or simple modifications to make it more left-handed friendly. On many Benelli models, you can turn the factory safety around so that pushing with your left index finger goes from safe to fire. That plus an oversized bolt handle go a long way to make it very usable for a lefty. Of course, you'll still have shells ejecting across your field of vision, but you really should try this to see if it bothers you.
